Sentence: [00:00.000 --> 00:06.240]: Hello. Good morning. This is Dr. Smith from the Brigham and Women's Hospital OB anesthesia team.
[00:06.520 --> 00:13.780]: I'm looking for Ms. Jane Blink. Yes, this is she. Good morning. Good morning. Your OB team asked
[00:13.780 --> 00:19.700]: our team to reach out with you to talk about some anesthesia related considerations given some of
[00:19.700 --> 00:25.160]: your history in this current pregnancy. Do you have about 15 minutes to speak with us? Yeah,
[00:25.160 --> 00:32.880]: they mentioned that someone from anesthesia will call me. Okay, perfect. We've reviewed your chart
[00:32.880 --> 00:37.880]: and we'd just like to discuss some of the findings from your most recent imaging in the
[00:37.880 --> 00:44.540]: pregnancy, if that's okay? Yeah. Great. I know from the ultrasound you have some findings that
[00:44.540 --> 00:49.900]: are concerning for placenta accreta spectrum, is that right? Yeah, my doctor said that. Okay,
[00:49.900 --> 00:51.700]: what did they tell you about that?
[00:54.680 --> 01:06.060]: the placenta may be implanted in the wrong place and very deep and because of that I may be
[01:06.060 --> 01:12.480]: bleeding or they may have to do a hysterectomy. They may have to remove the uterus and I won't
[01:12.480 --> 01:19.340]: be able to have more children. Yes, those are always a possibility with placenta accreta
[01:19.340 --> 01:24.440]: because the placenta is attached in an abnormal way to the uterus.
[01:24.680 --> 01:28.400]: We're here to just talk about some other things that we kind of consider
[01:28.400 --> 01:33.320]: in these cases. Mm-hm. Now, based on the ultrasound I see
[01:33.320 --> 01:39.260]: that the baby's also fairly large? Yeah. Okay, but the fluid around the baby looks normal so no polyhydramnios.
[01:39.260 --> 01:41.100]: Now, based on the ultrasound I see that the baby's also fairly large? Yeah. Okay, but the fluid around the baby looks normal so no
[01:41.100 --> 01:49.780]: polyhydramnios. I do see that you have two pretty big fibroids as well. I had a lot of
[01:49.780 --> 02:00.140]: of ultrasounds before getting pregnant and those were always big. Got it. Otherwise I see no
[02:00.140 --> 02:07.240]: preeclampsia so far in that pregnancy, is that right? No. Are you taking any blood thinner? I just take a baby aspirin
[02:07.240 --> 02:14.460]: every day in the morning. Okay, very good. And I also see some more recent labs in this pregnancy. I see
[02:14.460 --> 02:20.460]: that your hemoglobin and hematocrit values are 9 and 27, which are a bit on the lower side.
[02:21.380 --> 02:28.260]: Yeah, my blood counts have been always on the lower side but now during pregnancy my
[02:28.260 --> 02:39.320]: doctor was concerned so I'm taking some iron with the vitamins most of the days.
[02:39.560 --> 02:44.240]: Perfect, that's great. Your platelet count, which helps with
[02:44.460 --> 02:51.580]: is also a little on the low side. It's 140, but still on an okay range. I'm just gonna talk a
[02:51.580 --> 02:58.700]: little bit more about some of your gynecologic history, if that's okay. Yeah. Okay, so I see
[02:58.700 --> 03:06.620]: that you have some history of several DNCs, is that right? Yeah, it was very hard to get pregnant.
[03:06.620 --> 03:17.020]: We tried everything, and it was hard. There were, I had three miscarriages. Okay, sorry to hear that.
[03:17.020 --> 03:22.700]: I'm glad to hear that you're now pregnant. Otherwise, you've had a few other procedures
[03:22.700 --> 03:35.260]: on the uterus, is that right? Yeah, I had fibroids my whole life, and when I was younger, I had
[03:36.620 --> 03:47.180]: two procedures to remove fibroids, and then just recently, before I got pregnant, I had another
[03:47.180 --> 03:54.860]: surgery where they actually had to do like a big incision on my belly. Okay, I see. Yeah, I see in
[03:54.860 --> 03:59.980]: your past surgical history here that you've had two hysteroscopic removals of the myonectomies
[03:59.980 --> 04:05.260]: through the vagina and the uterus, and the other, they did the incision. Yeah, yeah.
[04:06.620 --> 04:12.300]: And I have had a couple of other surgeries in the abdomen, is that right? Yeah, I've had Crohn's
[04:12.300 --> 04:18.540]: disease since I was a teenager. Okay, so you've had a couple of surgeries, at least for that,
[04:18.540 --> 04:24.460]: it sounds like. Yeah, and I take medication. Okay, you currently have an ostomy, is that right? Yeah. Okay,
[04:25.340 --> 04:32.380]: got any other surgeries in your abdomen or in your pelvis other than those? No, this is,
[04:33.420 --> 04:35.180]: this is the only problem. Okay,
[04:36.620 --> 04:42.300]: very good. Do you have any bleeding disorders that we know of? No. Any clotting disorder? No. Great.
[04:42.300 --> 04:47.820]: Have you ever had a blood transfusion for any reason? No. Okay, and this pregnancy
[04:48.380 --> 04:54.220]: was conceived by IVF, is that right? Yeah, we had many cycles of IVF, and this one
[04:54.940 --> 05:01.340]: finally worked. I'm glad to hear that. I'm glad too. Yes, we're going to ask a little more about
[05:01.340 --> 05:06.060]: some of your baseline medical history as well, is that okay? Yeah. Do you have any
[05:06.620 --> 05:13.660]: heart problems? No. Do you have any lung problems? I have had asthma now for a while.
[05:14.780 --> 05:22.140]: It started a couple of years ago, but most of the times when I take the inhaler,
[05:23.660 --> 05:31.820]: it's under control. Okay, do you take a medication daily for that? It's mostly an inhaler,
[05:32.620 --> 05:36.300]: and I take it when I kind of feel tight. Okay. Maybe
[05:36.620 --> 05:43.260]: once a week or so, maybe once every other week. Okay. Have you ever been hospitalized for the
[05:43.260 --> 05:52.860]: asthma? No. No, okay. Otherwise, any high blood pressure? No. Great. How are you doing in terms
[05:52.860 --> 05:59.180]: of activity levels at this point in pregnancy? I've been pretty good, no problems. Great. Are
[05:59.180 --> 06:06.220]: you allergic to anything? No. Great. Do you have any personal or family-related problems with anesthesia?
[06:06.620 --> 06:14.780]: No. Great. Any scoliosis in the back? No. Awesome. And any hardware or back surgeries,
[06:14.780 --> 06:20.060]: things like that? No. Great. All right, thank you for answering all those questions. I know that it's
[06:20.060 --> 06:24.700]: a lot, but it's very helpful for us to have all the information so we can
[06:24.700 --> 06:30.860]: take excellent care of you. Okay, so some of your history, especially this placenta
[06:30.860 --> 06:36.620]: creative finding, as well as the many prior procedures in your uterus, do you put you on a
[06:36.620 --> 06:42.180]: a higher risk of bleeding during this c-section. Yeah. That's probably why we want to make a good
[06:42.180 --> 06:47.280]: plan with you and make sure that you are on board before the actual day of surgery, okay?
[06:48.380 --> 06:54.900]: So the plan will be for a cesarean section, is that right? Yeah, and the doctor said that
[06:54.900 --> 07:02.000]: they may have to remove my uterus, which I really hope doesn't happen because this is our first
[07:02.000 --> 07:09.300]: child and we were hoping for one more. Sure, totally understand that. Our hope is that this
[07:09.300 --> 07:14.400]: all goes as smoothly as possible. We're going to help make sure we can do everything we can to
[07:14.400 --> 07:23.700]: keep you safe, okay? I know this is your first c-section. Yeah. Typically, the anesthesia for
[07:23.700 --> 07:29.400]: these surgeries is what's called norexial, which means epidural or spinal. This means you'll get
[07:29.400 --> 07:31.880]: an injection that keeps you numb from...
[07:32.000 --> 07:37.240]: Your mid-chest and downward, so that you're able to have surgery while still being awake and kind
[07:37.240 --> 07:44.780]: of seeing when baby is born and things like that, okay? Yeah, I've never had that. Is that going to
[07:44.780 --> 07:53.040]: control my pain? Because with the Crohn's disease, it's been a lot of stomach pain.
[07:53.400 --> 08:00.500]: I'm sure that it has. Yeah, so the spinal or epidural are both really great in terms of
[08:02.000 --> 08:05.740]: Yeah, pain control both during the surgery to make sure that you're comfortable, but we also give
[08:05.740 --> 08:12.600]: medications that stay in your system for the first 24 hours that help with some of the baseline
[08:12.600 --> 08:19.700]: initial pain that you'll have during the first day coming out of surgery, okay? We'll also get
[08:19.700 --> 08:25.540]: other oral and IV medications for pain control as needed all throughout the post-op period, okay?
[08:27.120 --> 08:30.940]: Now, for someone who's c-section might be less straightforward because
[08:30.940 --> 08:36.940]: of your many prior surgeries in your abdomen as well as in your uterus and
[08:36.940 --> 08:42.080]: because of the placenta is a little bit abnormally attached, it may take longer
[08:42.080 --> 08:49.800]: than normal, so we might opt for a longer acting option for your anesthesia. That
[08:49.800 --> 08:54.920]: usually means either combined spinal epidural or a long spinal. What that might
[08:54.920 --> 08:59.320]: mean is that you might get an injection to get you numb into the spinal space, but
[08:59.320 --> 08:59.920]: we might also thread in an epidural.
[09:00.940 --> 09:06.100]: catheter so that we can give you more doses of numbing medication in case the
[09:06.100 --> 09:13.120]: surgery goes long yeah I'm really worried about pain because after my
[09:13.120 --> 09:19.120]: crown surgery I had a lot of pain and I had to take one medication and it was
[09:19.120 --> 09:24.640]: making me very nauseous they gave me another medication and it was just so
[09:24.640 --> 09:30.940]: painful the recovery was long well we will absolutely make sure that during
[09:30.940 --> 09:34.880]: the surgery that you are not having any pain that's one of our number one
[09:34.880 --> 09:41.080]: priorities and then we can also adjust the dosing of some of our medications
[09:41.080 --> 09:45.400]: for post-op pain so that you get higher than usual doses so it'll make sure that
[09:45.400 --> 09:51.760]: it's well controlled enough for you yeah thank you I usually take a lot to to get
[09:51.760 --> 09:54.400]: me comfortable I don't know why
[09:54.400 --> 09:54.600]: but I'm sure it's going to be okay for you
[09:54.600 --> 09:54.620]: but I'm sure it's going to be okay for you
[09:54.620 --> 10:00.380]: with the Crohn's disease it was a lot okay that can we can often see that on
[10:00.380 --> 10:03.940]: patients who have Crohn's disease and have had many procedures in the past
[10:03.940 --> 10:11.220]: okay now in terms of some of the other things we will always do at least one IV
[10:11.220 --> 10:15.620]: for anyone who's delivering or having a c-section in your case because you're at
[10:15.620 --> 10:19.860]: a higher risk of bleeding will likely place two IVs that way we have good
[10:19.860 --> 10:24.580]: access to give you fluids and medications okay we may need to use a
[10:24.580 --> 10:31.840]: ultrasound to find some bigger veins in your arms if needed we can give some
[10:31.840 --> 10:36.680]: numbing medication to the skin before using those bigger IVs okay okay I never
[10:36.680 --> 10:42.820]: had problems with IV that's good to hear now sometimes you also place a special
[10:42.820 --> 10:47.740]: IV called an arterial line basically instead of going into the vein it goes
[10:47.740 --> 10:54.540]: into the artery to help monitor your blood pressure on a basis rather than waiting for the blood pressure to be in the vein
[10:54.540 --> 11:01.040]: cuff to cycle we only do that if you're having kind of more significant bleeding
[11:01.040 --> 11:05.420]: and we need a tighter control of your blood pressure yeah they mentioned that
[11:05.420 --> 11:13.620]: before when I was having the fibroid surgery but it was okay okay good to know
[11:13.620 --> 11:18.340]: now we'll be communicating closely with your OP team about blood loss all
[11:18.340 --> 11:22.780]: throughout the surgery okay if you have significant blood loss we might give you
[11:22.780 --> 11:23.580]: a variety of medications to help you broken out of the vein and to improve your
[11:23.580 --> 11:29.620]: medications to help your uterus thicken tract, or to help prevent the breakdown of clotting factors in the blood.
[11:30.480 --> 11:37.000]: Based on your history, there's one that we will probably avoid called Hemabate. It can exacerbate asthma for people.
[11:37.140 --> 11:41.300]: Okay. But the other ones should all be safe for you to use. Okay.
[11:42.040 --> 11:46.340]: Now if you have significant blood loss, we might need to do a blood transfusion.
[11:46.340 --> 11:52.080]: Mm-hmm. Only if necessary, are you okay receiving a blood transfusion? Yeah, I understand. Very good.
[11:52.080 --> 12:00.860]: Now if bleeding is very significant, or if your OB decides to proceed with the removal of the uterus, or something more invasive,
[12:01.480 --> 12:08.020]: we might adjust our anesthetic plan. Okay. Even if the spinal or epidural anesthesia is working,
[12:08.080 --> 12:15.120]: we may need to convert to general anesthesia, where you're completely asleep with a breathing tube for your safety,
[12:15.400 --> 12:17.400]: depending on how things look. Mm-hmm.
[12:18.200 --> 12:21.360]: Now we'll communicate that with you before any of that happens.
[12:22.080 --> 12:24.880]: But we'll give IV medications that would make you fall asleep.
[12:25.300 --> 12:31.580]: And once you're asleep, we place a breathing tube to have good control over your airway and breathing. Okay. Okay.
[12:33.020 --> 12:40.820]: Now if that does happen, and you have a breathing tube, our goal is always for it to be a temporary measure during the surgery itself.
[12:41.700 --> 12:47.720]: However, if you require more interventions or more transfusions before becoming medically stable,
[12:48.600 --> 12:50.600]: we sometimes send you to an ICU
[12:50.600 --> 12:54.460]: for a closer monitoring until we can fully wake you up.
[12:55.580 --> 12:57.980]: If that happens, we'll give you a sedating medication
[12:58.820 --> 13:02.260]: up until the point that the breathing tube comes out, okay? Okay.
[13:03.120 --> 13:05.480]: And I know that's a lot, that's a very uncommon event,
[13:07.140 --> 13:11.520]: but we want to kind of talk about all the possibilities and let you know that we're planning for everything to keep you safe, okay?
[13:14.320 --> 13:17.980]: I know it's a lot of information, it can be very, very overwhelming.
[13:17.980 --> 13:25.260]: um what questions do you have about any of that um i'm just worried about pain because my doctor
[13:25.260 --> 13:33.480]: said that um the she would do everything to preserve my uterus and it may be a really long
[13:33.480 --> 13:43.160]: procedure so like what can i have for pain during the procedure or afterward yeah um both sure so
[13:43.160 --> 13:49.200]: you should not have pain during the surgery itself um the medications in the epidural and
[13:49.200 --> 13:53.660]: spinal kind of take away the sensation of sharpness or pinching or anything like that
[13:53.660 --> 14:00.440]: during the surgery okay you may feel touch and pressure at times but you shouldn't have any like
[14:00.440 --> 14:05.660]: discomfort okay we're there with you the entire time to help ensure that you're comfortable enough
[14:05.660 --> 14:12.960]: that's our number one priority okay okay um now um like we said if the case
[14:12.960 --> 14:13.140]: you're in a situation where you're in a situation where you're in a situation where you're in a
[14:13.140 --> 14:18.460]: runs longer we can always dose up the epidural with more medication to keep you numb if at any
[14:18.460 --> 14:23.660]: point you're in too much pain or discomfort or it's not working anymore we can always have the
[14:23.660 --> 14:30.000]: back option of going to sleep with general anesthesia okay okay as we mentioned um we'll
[14:30.000 --> 14:34.780]: give medications into the epidural and spinal that will be in your system for the post-op period of
[14:34.780 --> 14:41.100]: time okay initially but you'll also have some scheduled oral options um and if needed we might
[14:41.100 --> 14:42.940]: give some iv medications
[14:42.940 --> 14:48.700]: uh and might use what's called a pca pump um to help with pain control afterward if you need it
[14:48.700 --> 14:57.280]: okay okay what other questions do you have um no other questions my biggest concern was my pain but
[14:57.280 --> 15:05.700]: thank you for explaining of course um right so before you hang up we will briefly have you speak
[15:05.700 --> 15:10.440]: with dr jones who is one of the attending anesthesiologists here at the bergman women's
[15:12.740 --> 15:18.000]: this is dr jones i'm one of the opi anesthesiologists here at the bergman women's
[15:18.000 --> 15:23.540]: hello hi there um i read your chart and was listening along to your conversation with dr
[15:23.540 --> 15:28.220]: smith uh it sounds like you mentioned some of our considerations for patients who have a higher
[15:28.220 --> 15:34.600]: bleeding risk yeah yeah okay i just want to make sure that you don't have any more questions about
[15:34.600 --> 15:42.360]: anything before we hang up um i i forgot to tell him that um when when i had surgery
[15:42.740 --> 15:52.400]: i had a running pain and i had this你是 this ringing pain uh back structure and i've managed immense
[15:52.400 --> 15:59.200]: chronic pain and i it just can't
[15:59.200 --> 16:00.760]: it just keeps popping up
[16:00.760 --> 16:05.400]: obviously you could tell us if you need to talk a little bit more

[16:05.400 --> 16:08.000]: yes the only problem is i python is жел logric funny because i have been trying to change a lot already umétaiti'm not glad i got a new Wei Apparently I got dilauded and that made me very nauseus so if possible I want a different medication for pain control okay that's good to know we used various kinds of opioid pain medications don't safety neck noncoantenexfashioned Pediatrics

[16:08.000 --> 16:08.860]: pain med rejections the ones that go into the spinal epidural are not dilaudd they're different okay and if you do need iv medications we have others that are not dilaudded okay havingU free yoga episode
[16:10.540 --> 16:16.060]: you it's been okay for you before um yeah morphine worked really well for me last time that's good to
[16:16.060 --> 16:21.980]: know we'll make note of that okay okay thank you so much of course um so we'll document everything
[16:21.980 --> 16:27.980]: we discussed on this phone call and a note in your electronic medical record so that the team taking
[16:27.980 --> 16:33.580]: care of you on the day of surgery knows what we discussed okay okay sounds good very good
[16:34.380 --> 16:38.700]: we'll keep you safe and comfortable all right thank you all right have a good one bye-bye
